tool.name: KmerFreq HA
tool.command:
kmerfreq_ha_2.0.py
--format_of_data=$data_format.fastq_fasta #if $data_format.fastq_fasta == "fastq" #for $i in $data_format.libraries --paired_fastq_input1=$i.input1 --paired_fastq_input2=$i.input2 #end for #else #for $i in $data_format.libraries --paired_fasta_input1=$i.input1 --paired_fasta_input2=$i.input2 #end for #end if
## Check if using default or custom parameters --default_full_settings_type=$default_full_settings.settings_type #if $default_full_settings.settings_type == "full" --kmer_size=$default_full_settings.kmer_size --read_length=$default_full_settings.read_length --ignore_first=$default_full_settings.ignore_first --ignore_last=$default_full_settings.ignore_last --use_num_bases=$default_full_settings.use_num_bases ## Don't need to expose -l input read list file param ## Don't need to expose output prefix --hash_size=$default_full_settings.hash_size --thread_num=$default_full_settings.thread_num --max_read_length=$default_full_settings.max_read_length --bloom_filter=$default_full_settings.bloom_filter --bloom_array_size=$default_full_settings.bloom_array_size --num_processing_steps=$default_full_settings.num_processing_steps #end if
## Output files --stat=$stat --gz_freq=$gz_freq --filelist=$filelist

param.label: What type of data are you using?
param.name: fastq_fasta

param.help: Default settings are suitable for most analyses. If you want full control, use Full parameter list
param.label: kmerfreq settings to use
param.name: settings_type

param.help: Kmer size should be set between 13 and 27
param.label: Kmer size
param.name: kmer_size

param.help: The read length used to get kmers. If this value is left blank, the actual length of the read will be used by default
param.label: Read length
param.name: read_length

param.help: This option is set when sequencing quality is low at the beginning of reads
param.label: Number of bases to ignore at the start of the read?
param.name: ignore_first

param.help: This option is set when sequencing quality is low at the end of reads
param.label: Number of bases to ignore at the end of the read
param.name: ignore_last

param.help: This option is used for when sequencing depth is too high. All bases will be used by default if this parameter is left blank.
param.label: Total number of bases to use for kmers
param.name: use_num_bases

param.help: KmerFreq will increase the hashset memory space when it is insufficient
param.label: Initial size of hash table
param.name: hash_size

param.help: For increasing processing speed of KmerFreq. This param should be less than the number of available CPU cores
param.label: Number of threads to use
param.name: thread_num

param.help: KmerFreq will allocate memory buffer based on the read length
param.label: Maximum read length
param.name: max_read_length

param.help: Reduce memory usage by using the Bloom filter to remove kmers with frequencies lower than or equal to 2
param.label: Use Bloom filter to reduce memory usage?
param.name: bloom_filter

param.help: This parameter can be calculated using this formula:(genome_size+genome_size*coverage*error_rate*kmer_size)*5/4
param.label: Set Bloom array size
param.name: bloom_array_size

param.help: More steps will use less memory but processing time will be increased
param.label: Number of steps to be used for KmerFreq processing
param.name: num_processing_steps

tool.help:
**What it does**
KmerFreq corrects the sequencing errors based on the kmer frequency spectrum (KFS). It assumes that most low-frequency Kmers were generated by sequencing errors, so the key of error correction is that the distinguish rate of the low-frequency and high-frequency Kmers, the larger Kmer size, the better of this effect but need more computing resource. In order to get an accurate result, we balanced the trimmed length and delete ratio with the accuracy level. The practical Kmer size should be chosen based on the genome characteristic.
30X data is preferred for calculation of the Kmer frequency spectrum.
-----
**Outputs**
Two output files are generated by KmerFreq:
1. stat 2. freq
